page.title: 4.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will apply your understanding of average rate of change to interpret or create graphs of functions that are less well defined and that model real-life situations that are more complex.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain the average rate of change of a function in terms of a situation.
  • Describe important features of a graph and explain what they mean in a situation.
  • Sketch a graph that shows important features of the situation, given a description or a visual representation of a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.8.1: Analyzing and Comparing the Properties of Graphs
  • 4.8.2: Interpreting Graphs Without Units
  • 4.8.2: Self Check
  • 4.8.3: Sketching Graphs of Functions
  • 4.8.3: Self Check
  • 4.8.4: Using Verbal Descriptions to Create Graphs of Functions
  • 4.8.5: Representing Quantities in a Situation

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.8.6: Practice
  • 4.8.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.8.1: Analyzing and Comparing the Properties of Graphs
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Which graph doesn’t belong?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

A doesn't belong because:

  • It is the only graph that has no maximum or minimum.
  • It is the only situation in which the temperature does not change.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

B doesn't belong because:

  • It is the only graph that has one maximum.
  • It is the only graph that shows the temperature rising and then falling (but not rising again).


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

C doesn't belong becauses:

  • It is the only graph that has horizontal intercepts.
  • It is the only graph that has one minimum.
  • It is the only graph that shows negative output values or negative temperatures.
  • It is the only graph that shows temperature falling and then rising (but not falling.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

D doesn't belong becauses:

  • It is the only graph that has several maxima and minima.
  • It is the only graph where the temperature rises and falls several times.
  • This graph shows a repeating pattern.

page.title: 4.8.2: Interpreting Graphs Without Units
page.contents:
Activity

A flag ceremony is held at a Fourth of July event. The height of the flag is a function of time.

Here are some graphs that could each be a possible representation of the function.



    1. For each graph assigned to you, explain what it tells us about the flag. 

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • Graph A: The flag starts out on the ground but is immediately raised at a constant rate.
  • Graph B: The flag starts out at 3 meters above ground and then stays at that height the entire time.
  • Graph C: The flag starts out on the ground but gets pulled up quickly. The movement slows down and there is a brief pause, and then it is raised up again at a quicker and quicker rate.
  • Graph D: The flag starts out on the ground, is raised up a couple of meters, and then is lowered back to the ground. This happens repeatedly.
  • Graph E: The flag starts out at 0.5 meter above the ground and is raised up bit by bit, with a brief pause before it is raised farther.
  • Graph F: The flag starts out on the ground and is raised up at a constant speed for 3 seconds. It stops abruptly and comes back down at a constant speed. Then, 2 seconds later, it stops at 3 meters above the ground.


    1. Decide as a group which graph(s) appear to be most realistic and which ones least realistic.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Graph E seems the most realistic. Graphs B and D are the least realistic. Graphs A, C, and F are possible, but it is unlikely that the flag starts out being on the ground.



Video: Interpreting Graphs Without Units

Watch the following video to learn more about how to determine if a graph is realistic when it doesn’t have units.



  1. Here is another graph that relates time and height.


  1. Can this graph represent the time and height of the flag? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

(assuming that time is measured in seconds and height in meters):

No. This graph shows the flag being at all heights between 0 and 6 meters at 3 seconds of time, which is impossible.



  1. Is this a graph of a function? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

(assuming that time is measured in seconds and height in meters):

No, it is not a graph of a function. A function has only one output for every input. This graph shows many possible outputs when the input is 3.


Making a Real-World Connection

Suppose an ant is moving at a rate of 1 millimeter per second and keeps going at that rate for a long time. If time, \(x\), is measured in seconds, then the distance the ant has traveled in millimeters, \(y\), is \(y=1x\). If time, \(x\), is measured in minutes, the distance in millimeters is \(y=60x\).

  1. Explain why the equation \(y=(365\cdot24\cdot3600)x\) gives the distance the ant has traveled, in millimeters, as a function of time, \(x\), in years.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Sample response: The number of seconds in a year is \(365\cdot24\cdot60\cdot60\). If the ant travels 1 millimeter a second, in one year, it would travel \(365\cdot24\cdot3600\) millimeters. In \(x\) years, it would travel \((365\cdot24\cdot3600)x\) millimeters.




    1. Name the axes with appropriate quantities and units.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(x\)-axis: time (years), \(y\)-axis: distance traveled (millimeters)


    1. Using graphing technology outside of this course, graph the equation. Enter a description of your graph, then click solution to compare your answer.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:


    1. Does the graph look like that of a function? Why do you think it looks this way?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph is a vertical line and doesn’t look like a graph of a function. The slope is really large, so the line is so steep that it looks vertical.


  1. Using graphing technology outside of this course, adjust the graphing window until the graph no longer looks this way. If you manage to do so, describe the graphing window that you use.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph is a slanted line when the \(x\)-axis is scaled from –0.0001 to 0.0001 years and the \(y\)-axis is scaled to ten thousands in both directions.


  1. Do you think the last graph in the flag activity could represent a function relating time and height of the flag? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Flag F can represent a function because every input goes to exactly one output.

page.title: 4.8.2: Self Check
page.contents: Shannon is running on a flat, rocky trail that eventually rises up a steep mountain. Which graph below represents the total distance she covers with respect to time?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: She is able to start out faster since the trail is flat, but as the trail rises up the steep mountain, her rate tapers off.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This graph reflects a constant rate. The trail Shannon is running becomes steeper, which will slow down her pace. The answer is:
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You are looking for the graph of her distance traveled, so it should start at \((0,0)\) The answer is:
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You are looking for the graph of her distance traveled, so it should start at \((0,0)\) The answer is:

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.8.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Interpreting Graphs of Functions

The graph below represents the total number of smartphones that are shipped to a retail store over the course of days.

Match each part of the graph (A, B, and C) to its verbal description. Explain the reasoning behind your choice.

  1. Half of the factory workers went on strike, and not enough smartphones were produced for normal shipments.
    C; if half of the workers went on strike, then the number of smartphones produced would be less than normal. The rate of change for C is less than the rate of change for A.

  2. The production schedule was normal, and smartphones were shipped to the retail store at a constant rate.
    A; if the production schedule is normal, the rate of change of interval A is greater than the rate of change of interval C.

  3. A defective electronic chip was found, and the factory had to shut down, so no smartphones were shipped.
    B; if no smartphones are shipped to the store, the total number remains constant during that time.

Try It: Interpreting Graphs of Functions

The relationship between Jameson’s account balance and time is modeled by the graph below.


Write a story that models the situation represented by the graph.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample Response:

Jameson was sick and did not work for almost a whole week. Then, he mowed several lawns over the next few days and deposited the money into his account after each job. It rained several days, so instead of working, Jameson withdrew money from his account each day to go to the movies and out to lunch with friends.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.8.3: Sketching Graphs of Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will show a video of a flag being raised. Function \(H\) gives the height of the flag over time. Height is measured in feet. Time is measured in seconds since the flag is fully secured to the string, which is when the video clip begins.



  1. Use the Desmos graphing tool above or technology outside the course.

    On the coordinate plane, sketch a graph that could represent function \(H\). Be sure to include a label and a scale for each axis.

Select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

page.title: 4.8.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Graphing Situations as Functions

Example 1:

Draw a graph representing a function that describes Sam’s distance from home over an hour.

A: Sam rides his bike to his friend’s house at a constant rate for 20 minutes.
B: Sam plays for 20 minutes at his friend’s house.
C: Sam and his friend bike together to an ice cream shop that is between their houses for 20 minutes.

Here is a sample graph. Notice that the \(x\)-axis is labeled “time in minutes” and the \(y\)-axis is labeled “distance from home (miles).”

The distance from home is increasing as Sam rides to his friend’s house. While playing at his friend’s house, the distance remained constant and unchanged. When Sam left his friend’s house for the ice cream shop, the distance from home decreased because the shop is in between their houses, so Sam was getting closer to home.

Example 2:

Tyler filled up his bathtub, took a bath, and then drained the tub. The function gives the depth of the water \(B\), in inches, \(t\) minutes after Tyler began to fill the bathtub.

These statements describe how the water level in the tub was changing over time. Use the statements to sketch an approximate graph of the function.

  • \(B(0) = 0\)
  • \(B(1) < B(7)\)
  • \(B(9) = 11\)
  • \(B(10) = B(20)\)
  • \(B(20) > B(40)\)

A sample graph below meets all of the statements above.

Try It: Graphing Situations as Functions

A rock climber begins her descent from a height of 50 feet. She slowly descends at a constant rate for 4 minutes. She takes a break for 1 minute; she then realizes she left some of her gear on top of the rock and climbs more quickly back to the top at a constant rate.

Create a graph representing this situation.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to graph the situation:

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.8.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Marcus is going to the library with his friend Monica.

  • Monica lives between the library and Marcus’s house.
  • Marcus lives 0.5 mile from Monica, and she lives 0.25 mile from the library.
  • Marcus walks to Monica’s house in 5 minutes, and he stays there for 15 minutes before they walk together to the library in 3 minutes.

If you were sketching a graph of Marcus’s distance from home in miles with respect to time, in minutes, how would you represent the 15 minutes he was at Monica’s house graphically?

answer.answer_text: A vertical line connecting \((5, 0.5)\) and \((5, 20)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: A vertical line would indicate that Marcus was in 2 different places at the exact same time. The answer is a horizontal line connecting \((5, 0.5)\) and \((20, 0.5)\).

answer.answer_text: A line with a constant rate connecting \((0,0)\) and \((5, 0.5)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the line that represents the distance from when Marcus leaves his house until he gets to Monica’s house. The answer is a horizontal line connecting \((5, 0.5)\) and \((20, 0.5)\).

answer.answer_text: A line with a constant rate connecting \((0,0)\) and \((20, 0.5)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would represent Marcus taking 20 minutes to walk to Monica’s house. The answer is a horizontal line connecting \((5, 0.5)\) and \((20, 0.5)\).

answer.answer_text: A horizontal line connecting \((5, 0.5)\) and \((20, 0.5)\)
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: When Marcus arrives at Monica’s house, 5 minutes have passed and he is 0.5 mile from home. This is represented by \((5, 0.5)\). While at Monica’s, time passes, but the distance does not change. This can be represented by \((20, 0.5)\). Since the distance is the same, the line is horizontal.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.8.4: Using Verbal Descriptions to Create Graphs of Functions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

To prepare for a backyard party, a parent uses two identical hoses to fill a small pool that is 15 inches deep and a large pool that is 27 inches deep.

The height of the water in each pool is a function of time since the water is turned on.

Here are descriptions of three situations. For each situation, sketch the graphs of the two functions on the same coordinate plane, so that S(t) is the height of the water in the small pool after t minutes, and L(t) is the height of the water in the large pool after t minutes.

In both functions, the height of the water is measured in inches.


  • Situation 1: Each hose fills one pool at a constant rate. When the small pool is full, the water for that hose is shut off. The other hose keeps filling the larger pool until it is full.


Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Show the graph of situation 1:

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:



  • Situation 2: Each hose fills one pool at a constant rate. When the small pool is full, both hoses are shut off.


Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Show the graph of situation 2:

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:



  • Situation 3: Each hose fills one pool at a constant rate. When the small pool is full, both hoses are used to fill the large pool until it is full.


Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Show the graph of situation 3:

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

page.title: 4.8.5: Representing Quantities in a Situation
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Your teacher will show you one or more videos of a tennis ball being dropped. Here are some still images of the situation.

The height of the ball is a function of time. Suppose the height is \(h\) feet, \(t\) seconds after the ball is dropped.

  1. Use the blank coordinate plane to sketch a graph of the height of the tennis ball as a function of time. To help you get started, here are some pictures and a table.

0 seconds

0.28 seconds

0.54 seconds

0.74 seconds

1.03 seconds

1.48 seconds

1.88 seconds

2.25 seconds

  1. Complete the table with your estimates.

Time (seconds)

Height (feet)

0

A. ______

0.28

B. ______

0.54

C. ______

0.74

D. ______

1.03

E. ______

1.48

F. ______

1.88

G. ______

2.25

H. ______

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  1. 6
  2. 4.3
  3. 0
  4. 2.2
  5. 3.5
  6. 0
  7. 2
  8. 0


  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Use the table of values to sketch your graph.

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:



  1. Identify the \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts of the graph. Explain what the coordinates tell us about the tennis ball.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\((0,6)\) is the \(y\)-intercept. It is the height from which the tennis ball is dropped. \((0.54,0)\), \((1.48,0)\), and \((2.25,0)\) are three of the \(x\)-intercepts. They represent the times at which the ball hits the ground.



  1. Find the maximum and minimum values of the function. Explain what they tell us about the tennis ball.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The maximum value of the function is 6, at \(t=0\). The height from which the ball is dropped, 6 feet, is its greatest height. The minimum value is 0, at multiple points when the tennis ball hits the ground.



Making a Real-World Connection

If you only see the still images of the ball and not the video of the ball bouncing, can you accurately graph the height of the ball as a function of time? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

No, each still image gives the position of the ball at a different time, or one point on the graph that represents height as a function of time. But without the video, we would not know what is happening at the time the image is taken: Is the ball going up? Is it coming down? Is it at one of its peaks?

page.title: 4.8.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The graphs show the distance, \(d\), traveled by two cars, A and B, over time, \(t\). Distance is measured in miles, and time is measured in hours.

Correct! Car A traveled slower because Car B was a farther distance in the same amount of time as Car A.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.8.1–4.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Car A traveled slower because Car B was a farther distance in the same amount of time as Car A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 2–5, use the graphs below to match each description of a situation in which the volume of water in a tank is a function of time to its corresponding graph.

Graph 1

Graph 2

Graph 3

Graph 4

  1. An empty 20-gallon water tank is filled at a constant rate for 3 minutes until it is half full. Then, it is emptied at a constant rate for 3 minutes.

Correct! Graph 3

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A full 10-gallon water tank is drained for 30 seconds, until it is half full. Afterward, it gets refilled.

Correct! Graph 1

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A 2,000-gallon water tank starts out empty. It is being filled for 5 hours, slowly at first, and faster later.

Correct! Graph 2

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. An empty 100-gallon water tank is filled in 50 minutes. Then, a dog jumps in and splashes around for 10 minutes, letting 7 gallons of water out. The tank is refilled afterward.

Correct! Graph 4

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph 4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 6–7, use this situation and function:
The daily cost to the manufacturing company is modeled by the function \(C(x)=7.25x+2500\), where \(C(x)\) is the total daily cost and \(x\) is the number of items manufactured.

  1. What is \(C(0)\)? Enter only integers.

Correct! 2500

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 2,500. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does C(0) mean in the context of the situation?

Correct! Cost before any items are manufactured

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.8.1–4.8.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is cost before any items are manufactured. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.8.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the average rate of change of a function in terms of a situation.
  • Describe important features of a graph and explain what they mean in a situation.
  • Sketch a graph that shows important features of the situation, given a description or a visual representation of a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.8.1: Analyzing and Comparing the Properties of Graphs
    • In this activity, you analyzed and compared graphs that did not have units of measure on the axes. Vocabulary words from prior lessons, such as “maximum,” “minimum,” “increasing,“ and “decreasing,” were used to review and to describe the graphs.
  • 4.8.2: Interpreting Graphs Without Units
    • In this activity, you described different graphs that all represented the same situation. You determined which graph best matched the scenario, and which graphs were the least logical considering the scenario. The importance of an appropriate viewing window for technology was also discovered in this activity. You also reviewed the graph of a vertical line, including how it is not a function and why it would not work in the real-world scenario.
  • 4.8.2: Self Check
  • 4.8.3: Sketching Graphs of Functions
    • In this activity, you had to create the graph of function after watching a video of a situation. You had to share and discuss vocabulary, including the different key features of your graph. There was an opportunity to discuss differences in graphs and determine which best reflected the situation from the video.
  • 4.8.3: Self Check
  • 4.8.4: Using Verbal Descriptions to Create Graphs of Functions
    • In this activity, you used several different written or verbal descriptions to create graphs. You had to consider the context of the situation to know when one or both of the graphs became constant.
  • 4.8.5: Representing Quantities in a Situation
    • In this activity, you watched a video of a tennis ball being dropped and used the video and still pictures from it to approximate values to sketch a graph. You were then asked specific questions about key features of your sketch.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.8.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
